awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2023 Empirical Software Engineering International Week (ESEIW)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports students to travel to and attend the 2023 Empirical Software Engineering International Week (ESEIW) in New Orleans, Louisiana occurring October 23-27, 2023. The main event is the 17th ACM/IEEE International Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement (ESEM), which is surrounded by workshops and mentoring events, such as a doctoral symposium and a course on Analytical Observational Studies in Software Engineering where sound empirical methods are taught.  The grant provides US-based students with the opportunity to hear presentations of current research and meet the community of researchers to enhance their education and advance research goals.   The grant helps build the future workforce in software engineering practice, research and education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT WILMINGTON

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington

por.por_cntn:
Nine students from US universities were awarded grants to defray travel costs (transportation, lodging, registration fees) of attending events during the 2023 Empirical Software Engineering International Week (ESEIW) in New Orleans, Louisiana October 23 to 27, 2023. This annual event brings together researchers from academia and industry to present their work. The travel grant paid for conference registration fees and, for non-local students, lodging and air travel on US flag carriers. A total of 19 students applied for the grants, and eleven were selected based on selection criteria. Two declined due to travel considerations.

Intellectual merit: Seven of the nine awardees were doctoral students who presented empirical software engineering research findings conducted as part of their graduate studies. The goal of empirical software engineering research is to understand the human factors, process factors, and artifact factors that impact the quality of the software. At the conference, students discussed empirical research design, learned empirical research techniques, and presented their research. All awardees were paired with a senior research mentor at the conference, and the pair attended sessions together and discussed professional development. Awardees submitted a critical reflection, wherein they commented on the positive environment of the conference, the diversity of interesting research, the value of the networking opportunities, and the benefits of the mentor-mentee arrangement.

Broader impacts: Academic conferences like ESEIW afford the awardees invaluable networking opportunities as they begin their research careers. One objective of this travel grant was to encourage participation from women and other underrepresented minorities in Computer Science, as well as attendance by new participants to the empirical software engineering community. Two of the nine awardees identified as women, both of whom presented research papers. Six of the nine awardees identified as members of an underrepresented group. Finally, eight of the nine awardees were first-time attendees to the conference, including two attendees from local universities in New Orleans.


Last Modified: 03/10/2024
Modified by: Lucas Layman
